title: 115_hr6989
content: Restricting federal assistance benefits to verified citizens. Restriction on Federal assistance benefits: Individuals must meet citizenship requirement to be eligible for assistance under any Federal program. Individuals must meet citizenship requirements by attesting to their citizenship and verifying it to be eligible for Federal assistance benefits. Individuals applying for Federal assistance benefits must provide a written declaration confirming their U.S. citizenship or nationality and furnish satisfactory documentary evidence and a photographic identity document as part of the citizenship verification requirement. Individuals applying for Federal assistance benefits must provide a written declaration confirming their U.S. citizenship or nationality, furnish a photographic identity document, and provide their name and social security account number for verification. Individuals receiving Federal assistance benefits must provide documentary evidence and information to confirm their citizenship or nationality status, along with their name and social security account number. This information is then submitted to the Commissioner of Social Security for verification. Individuals receiving Federal assistance benefits must provide their name, social security number, and other identity information for verification by the Commissioner of Social Security. The Commissioner compares the submitted information with records to confirm the validity of the number and citizenship status. Confirmation can also be done through the Department of Homeland Security. The Social Security Administration verifies citizenship status of individuals receiving Federal assistance benefits. Information is submitted to the Department of Homeland Security for confirmation. The Department of Homeland Security confirms citizenship status based on submitted information. Entities must verify individuals through the SAVE Program to ensure they are not noncitizens. Individuals failing to provide required documentation will receive notice. The SAVE Program of the Department of Homeland Security verifies citizenship status. If an individual fails to provide documentation or confirmation of citizenship, they will be notified of their ineligibility for federal assistance benefits and given the opportunity to appeal. Federal agencies must provide an appeals process for individuals deemed ineligible for benefits. The federal benefit program allows individuals to appeal a determination of ineligibility for assistance benefits. Children or family members can meet citizenship requirements for benefits if a parent or guardian meets the criteria. The federal benefit program allows individuals to appeal ineligibility for assistance benefits. Household members can meet citizenship requirements if any individual in the household meets the criteria, with exceptions for elderly and disabled individuals in specific housing programs. The citizenship requirement for housing under section 811 of the Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act must be met by a disabled individual in the household. Once the requirement is satisfied for a Federal assistance benefit, it continues as long as the individual remains eligible. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget can issue regulations for implementation. The Director will specify the declaration form and verification process for citizenship within 30 days of the Act's enactment. The form will be based on the Social Security Act, and the verification process will be based on the process used for Social Security Act purposes. The provisions of this section supersede any laws related to eligibility for Federal assistance benefits based on citizenship, nationality, or immigration status, unless deemed more restrictive by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. Disqualification for willful and repeated noncompliance by entities providing Federal assistance benefits is determined by the Director if citizenship requirements are not met or information is not submitted as required. Federal assistance benefit entities must comply with citizenship requirements and submit required information. Failure to do so results in disqualification and inclusion on the List of Excluded Individuals/Entities until benefits are recovered. Inspectors general monitor compliance with the program. The term "Federal assistance program" refers to any provision of Federal law excluding the Internal Revenue Code. In this section, the term "Federal assistance program" is defined as any provision of Federal law authorizing benefits based on income or resources, including those under the Social Security Act. Subsection (a) applies to eligibility determinations made one year after the enactment of the Act, with a transition rule requiring citizenship verification within two years to maintain eligibility for benefits.
